metadata.title: Yes, You Can Become a Data Scientist Online. Here’s How. | by Matt Przybyla | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Yes, You Can Become a Data Scientist Online. Here’s How.
metadata.description: A guide to becoming a data scientist online and from home by online courses, online degrees, and extracurriculars: Coursera, Udemy, Metis, and Data Science.

all_paragraphs: Several articles highlight how difficult and farfetched it is to achieve success in data science by means of online courses or degrees. Since you are reading this article, perhaps you have some belief in self-learning and online learning success as well. Although data science seems to be an up-and-coming field, it has been here much longer than most realize. Think of the Google search engine — that is utilizing natural language processing (NLP), a facet of data science.

Data science can be grouped with people studying and working in data analytics, machine learning, artificial intelligence, data engineering, software engineering, statistics, and AB testing. Most, if not all of these fields have touched data science in some way. The most important part of learning data science is learning how to problem-solve. The main difference in traditional statistics and modern data science is automation. Say you were performing a regression analysis in Excel or SAS in the 2000s, what is different now? Now, there are programming languages that are prioritized when learning data science. Python, perhaps, is the most critical tool in automating traditional statistics. To go with Python, there are several libraries or packages that make data science a little easier and more efficient — sklearn, numpy, and pandas. These prove to work off similar or exact principles from researchers and scientists in the 1990s, but are now sped up for nearly instant results, inferences, and predictions. Never better than now, during a global pandemic, where offices and in-person institutions are halted, has it been the most appropriate time to learn online.
Below are several examples of how to become a successful data science online — from a professional data scientist who learned online.

Coursera [3] — an online platform offering extensive courses and specializations, as well as certificates. This program is run by Johns Hopkins University. You will learn a plethora of skills, including:

This program shows that about 43% of people start a new career and 19% got a pay increase or promotion after completing their courses. It is suggested that about 7 hours/week are needed to successfully complete this training in about 11 months. Because it is online, it is flexible in its 10 specializations, which include:

Coursera’s program is free to access — for reading and viewing the course content; however, if you want the certificate of completed work, then you will have to pay (there is financial aid as well). With completing this specialization, approved by learning professors and endorsed by companies like LinkedIn, Coursera is a great way to start your data science career.

Udemy [4]. Whereas Coursera focuses mainly on one central program, Udemy offers a wide variety of data science courses. Ranging from machine learning to Python, these courses are cheap and can be more specialized. Benefits of Udemy include:
Near 3 million students have learned from Udemy, whether it be to start from scratch, or to enhance or switch their career to fully data science-focused.

Metis [5]. This training is completely focused on data science from Kaplan — a highly reputable institution. Metis highlights it’s alumni, which rave about this platform. From established companies and startups, they have proven that their students do indeed find success. They work at companies like Facebook, Airbnb, IMB, Spotify, Apple, and BuzzFeed. To use their online platform, rather than an in-person bootcamp, they have a program named ‘Live Online’.
Metis is a hybrid option that offers online learning; an online bootcamp where attending a campus learning is not necessary.

The more expensive option is to traditionally obtain your degree from a university — but in a modern sense, online. It can be a riskier approach to the smaller course option as you will most likely spend thousands of dollars, but more professionally regarded in the workforce. There are countless universities, mostly for a master's degree.

The most comprehensive list is found here [7]. This site includes: top schools, online programs, by state, related degrees, careers, online courses, resources, bootcamps, and about 2U. Be sure to research your options, because this investment will pricier, but could help you the most in the long term.

My story: I attended Southern Methodist University (SMU) [8] online, with a masters of science in data science. I thoroughly enjoyed this program. Studying online, I was able to keep my current job and research in the evenings. The classes were live and you could stack them all on one evening or spread them out throughout the week. I was able to collaborate with classmates from around the world from different backgrounds; the diversity in the program was outstanding. Compared to my in-person undergraduate studies, I was able to apply most of my learnings from online way more effectively. I started my official analytics career at Indeed, then moved to HomeAway (Vrbo), and now work for ScaleFactor as a Data Scientist. I gained most of my experience from learning online. Most students start from scratch in data science, and some do not know coding as well in this program. By the end of the online university coursework, most of my friend’s careers changed in some positive way. For example, students changed from accounting or tech support positions to specialized data scientists, while I switched from analytical chemistry to data science.

Community. The online learning space has a surprisingly large community. Because social media is evolving and increasing, there have been several forms of extracurricular ways of learning. There are plenty of data science conferences that are now online rather than in-person. Some are recorded and can be viewed online as well. With Zoom and other conference platforms, being apart of the larger community has never been easier and more accessible.

A few other methods of learning are Skillshare and YouTube. Skillshare is more personalized than traditional online courses, and YouTube has thousands of videos from data scientists who have a passion for teaching a wide array of skills, whether it is programming in Python or R, or bridging the gap between data science and production machine learning with tools like Airflow and GitHub.

An increasing amount of careers are started with online learning, and data science is no exception. With working from home becoming more popular as well, accreditation or experience from online means has been regarded more, with new reputable avenues of achieving online learning success. I have learned nearly all my data science knowledge online, whether that be from SMU, some YouTube videos, or even tutorials from Towards Data Science.
After reading my article, I hope you find yourself with the motivation that you can start or enhance your data science career from home as well.
